description.en: The course will cover both the normative challenges of e-democracy as well as the practical domains of e-government. It will examine both scholarly research on these two phenomena as well as case studies on how they have been applied. Examples from Estonia and from other countries from around the world will be highlighted.
description.et: Kursus hõlmab e-demokraatia normatiivseid väljakutseid ning e-valitsuse praktilisi valdkondi. Esile tõstetakse näiteid Eestist ja teistest maailma riikidest.

objectives.en: This course will provide an overview of one of the key trends in democratic development - electronic democracy - and its counterpart in modern governance - electronic government. The objective will be to expose students to the latest trends that will be important for democracy and governance over the coming decades. The course is explicitly focused on e-government solutions and applications such as cloud based services, predictive services, blockchain, e-voting but nevertheless covering also the normative challenges that these present.
objectives.et: Aine annab ülevaate demokraatia arengu peamistest suundadest: elektroonilisest demokraatiast ja kaasaegsest juhtimisesest e-valitsuseni. Eesmärk on tutvustada kaasaegseid trende, mis muutuvad oluliseks demokraatia ja valitsemise jaoks tulevaste aastakümnete jooksul. Aine keskendub e-valitsuse lahendustele ja rakendustele, nt pilvepõhised teenused, ennustusteenused, blokkide loomine, e-hääletamine, smuti hõlmab teenuste normatiivseid väljakutseid.

learning_outcomes.et: Kursuse läbinud üliõpilased (1) mõistavad elektroonilise demokraatia olulisi normatiivseid ja empiirilisi mõõtmeid, (2) omavad ülevaadet võtmetähtsusega elektroonilistest vahenditest poliitilise osaluse ja kaasamise jaoks, (3) nimetavad ja kasutavad e-valitsuse olulisi struktuure ja platvorme, (4) kirjeldavad, kuidas e-demokraatiat ja e-valitsust saab tänapäeval rakendada juhtimises.

notes.et:
This course will provide an overview of one of the key trends in democratic development - electronic democracy - and its counterpart in modern governance - electronic government. The objective will be to expose students to the latest trends that will be important for democracy and governance over the coming decades.

The course is explicitly focused on e-government solutions and applications such as cloud based services, predictive services, blockchain, e-voting but nevertheless covering also the normative challenges that these present. It will examine both scholarly research on these two phenomena as well as case studies on how they have been applied. Examples from Estonia and from other countries from around the world will be highlighted.

This course can be followed remotely in case the student cannot be present in class due to travel restrictions.

description.et: *	Active contribution to the classes; missing more than four classes (without a valid excuse) results in not being admitted to grading;

*	Written group assignment (2-5 students): comparative study of various national digital government policies (50% of the grade). Students will be provided with the analytical frame for the comparison but have to pick the policy themselves and perform an analysis involving mostly desk research and secondary source analysis. Examples of possible policies to be analysed will be provided. Separate detailed instructions on the assignment will be provided in Moodle.

grade_preconditions.et: I assume the student attends the seminars and takes actively part in discussions. Missing more than four classes without a valid excuse results in not being admitted to grading.

description.et:
Introduction & welcome, in person
This lecture gives an overview of the themes of the course and introduces the requirements of the group assignment.

Digital Era Government (and its theoretical backgrounds), in person
This lecture gives an introduction to the concept of digital government/governance and the diffusion of digitalization in and across national contexts.

Development - waterfall and iteration, in person
This lecture will look at the Waterfall and Agile project management approaches in government, examining the good and bad sides of both. It will also explore the Government-as-a-Platform concept, including the Estonian example.

User-focus & design, in person 
This lecture looks at the challenges encountered in measuring the effects of digitalisation and human-centred design of digital public services.
Q&A intermediate briefing / review of assignment online
Overcoming legal and financial barriers, in person
Research directions and future challenges , online
